title: Woolworths store changes save $50m but 'smash' morale
text:
Mr Gillies, who had worked with Woolworths for more than 30 years, subsequently decided to accept the lower paying position last month but told The Australian Financial Review he was looking around for another job.

A woman who had worked for Woolworths for more than 20 years and was managing payroll at a store in Western Australia took redundancy after being told her $65,000 salary would be cut by $20,000.

At the same time, Woolworths has been tweaking rosters – delaying early starts and pulling forward late shifts – to boost service levels and ensure shelves are stocked when customers are shopping.

'Smashed morale'

Suppliers say the loss of experienced managers is causing disruption, while unions say store morale has taken a hit and could affect customers.

"Woolworths has lost some really good people," said one supplier, who declined to be named. "A lot of staff are leaving because their contracts have been changed."

The Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Union (SDA) and the Retail and Fast Food Workers Union (RAFFWU) helped thousands of staff secure new roles, exit with better redundancy arrangements or leave before the September 30 deadline without jeopardising redundancy payments.

"Several thousand matters have now been dealt with to the satisfaction of our members – thousands of employees have been successfully redeployed into comparable roles in Woolworths whilst other employees opted to take redundancy payments," an SDA spokeswoman said.

Advertisement

However RAFFWU secretary Josh Cullinan said the new store model and roster changes, which will reduce penalties for many staff, had 'smashed' morale.

"The fallout is those who are staying on in lower-paying jobs and the wholesale changes to rosters across the network," Mr Cullinan said. "It's smashed morale and destroyed their relationship with very long-term staff."

"We expect it will have a lasting and very significant impact on the staff experience and therefore the customer experience."

Woolworths' supermarkets managing director Claire Peters acknowledged the challenges for staff, saying: "We know organisational change is never easy for team members, particularly during the transition."

Woolworths head of supermarkets Claire Peters. Ben Rushton

"It’s a real credit to our stores that the team attitude measure in our voice of customer scores have remained stable throughout this challenging period," Ms Peters said.

"As we embed the new model, our customers will notice more team members on the shop floor, especially in key trading periods on weekends and after 6pm. These periods, which attract penalty rates, are when our customers want to shop and we’re aligning our rosters to meet these changing needs."

Advertisement

"This is key to underpinning the long-term health of our business and the 115,000 Australian jobs it helps support," Ms Peters said.

JP Morgan analyst Shaun Cousins estimates Woolworths will save $50 million a year through the new store operating model and roster changes, helping the retailer offset a $150 million increase in labour costs stemming from a new enterprise agreement.

"The benefits should all be in place in the second quarter and definitely by the second half," Mr Cousins said in a recent report.
description: Store management and roster changes will save Woolworths more than $50 million a year but have "smashed" staff morale.
